awd_titl_txt: Topics in Mathematical Theory of Adaptive Finite Element Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
Finite element methods (FEM) are widely used to approximately solve partial differential equations in simulations of physical phenomena arising in engineering and the physical sciences. Such simulations are an indispensable tool in the development and testing of new technologies.  Adaptive variants of finite element methods are designed to increase the efficiency and accuracy with which simulations can be carried out by making better use of computational resources and to increase confidence in the accuracy of simulations by providing researchers with a computable measure of the errors that arise in approximation techniques.  This research project aims to develop new variants of adaptive finite element methods and increase mathematical understanding of their underpinnings.  The project has two main foci.  The first is adaptive FEM for partial differential equations defined on surfaces, which arise for example in describing fluid flows with multiple components (such as oil and water). The second is development and analysis of adaptive FEM for controlling various measures of the error, especially maximum errors.

In the first project the investigator will construct and analyze adaptive variants of surface finite element methods with two main goals in mind.  First, while surface FEM are an established finite element methodology with many useful variants defined, adaptive versions of some important variants are missing.  This project aims to fill that gap.  Secondly, the project will explore the interaction between adaptive surface FEM, the way a given surface is represented in a finite element code, and the smoothness or regularity of the surface.  The result will be more robust adaptive surface codes that give users greater flexibility in representing surfaces while also making the best possible use of available information about the surface.  The second main project will lead to proof of convergence of adaptive algorithms for controlling maximum errors, and will also provide new adaptive algorithms for controlling maximum errors in a class of singularly perturbed elliptic problems.

por.por_cntn:
Surface partial differential equations (PDE) are used to model physical effects that occur on the interface between two different phases of matter, or on the surface of some physical object of interest.  For example, such equations describe the surface tension on a droplet of oil suspended in water and the biomembranes that compose the exterior layer of living cells.  In this project the PI and collaborators developed new numerical algorithms for approximatly solving such equations using surface finite element methods (SFEM), and also provided new error analysis for both new and existing algorithms of this type.  

One focus of this project was understanding adaptive finite element algorithms for surface PDE.  Adaptive finite element methods (AFEM) involve breaking a computational domain (here a surface) into a trianglular grid and then automatically deciding which triangles should be subdivided in order to best increase the fidelity of the resulting approximation.  In SFEM, the triangular grid approximates the underlying surface, and decisions about which triangles to subdivide should take into account both the ability of the grid to resolve the surface and its ability to resolve the solution to the given PDE.  The project led to a new algorithm that optimally takes both of these considerations into account.  In addition, the project led to new understanding of the effects of surface smoothness on the behavior of SFEM errors.  

Another focus of the project was new algorithms and error analysis for different types of surface PDE.  One focus was surface eigenvalue problems.  Eigenvalues of surfaces may be used to provide a sort of "DNA" or fingerprint of the surfaces shape, so computational comparison of these quantities has been used to computationally compare the shapes of objects.  This project led to deep understanding of the error behavior of SFEM when used to approximate such eigenvalues, along with error analysis of a corresponding surface adaptive FEM.  A Ph.D. student was also trained as part of this project.  A new algorithm for the surface Stokes equation, which describes the flow of fluids on surfaces, was also constructed and analyzed.  

Finally, this project led to new, rigorously grounded adaptive algorithm for controlling maximum errors in certain types of partial differential equations.  Standard error analysis for FEM only guarantee that the method gives good results "on the average", while establishing that the approximate solution is a good approximation to the actual one pointwise (everywhere in the domain) is substantially more difficult.
